docs.snippet: The Supreme Court’s rejection of a bill freeing about 120 political prisoners left some wondering whether lawmakers who are pushing for change have any real power....
docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s rejection of a bill freeing about 120 political prisoners left some wondering whether lawmakers who are pushing for change have any real power.
docs.abstract: Venezuela's courts, which are filled with loyalists to country's leftist government, have hindered opposition's effort to distance country from legacy of former Pres Hugo Chavez and successor Pres Nicolas Maduro; Supreme Court's overturning of law that would have freed about 120 political prisoners dealt strong blow to undertaking.

headline.main: Venezuela’s Court Deals Another Blow to Opposition Lawmakers
headline.print_headline: Venezuelan Courts Chip Away at Opposition’s Power

byline.contributor: María Eugenia Díaz and Patricia Torres contributed reporting.

docs.snippet: A year after the arrest of Freddie Gray, correspondents who have covered events in Baltimore since then took stock of the city’s mood and politics....
docs.lead_paragraph: A year after the arrest of Freddie Gray, correspondents who have covered events in Baltimore since then took stock of the city’s mood and politics.
docs.abstract: New York Times correspondents John Eligon and Sheryl Gay Stolberg have reported on events in Baltimore over past year; share excerpts from conversation in which they discuss current mind-set of city that is about to elect a new mayor and will soon see resumption of long-delayed trials of six police officers charged in 2015 death of black man Freddie Gray.

headline.main: Baltimore After Freddie Gray: The ‘Mind-Set Has Changed’
headline.print_headline: A Year After Gray’s Arrest, ‘Baltimore’s Mind-Set Has Changed’

byline.original: By JOHN ELIGON and SHERYL GAY STOLBERG
